dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Angel Au-Yeung from Forbes reported that Jeff Bezos sold over half a million shares of Amazon stock just last week.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Angel Au-Yeung from Forbes reported that Jeff Bezos sold over half a million shares of Amazon stock just last week.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: According to documents filed on Monday afternoon with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the worlds richest man sold over 530,000 shares of Amazon when the stock price was around $1,900 a share.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it's not the first time either—he sold a huge chunk back in July too, right? Like, 1.3 billion dollars after taxes.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it's not the first time either-he sold a huge chunk back in July too, right? Like, one point three billion dollars after taxes.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The sales on August 1 and 2 followed $1.4 billion (after-tax) worth of Amazon stock he sold in the final three days of July.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And the prevailing explanation seems to be that he's funding Blue Origin with these sales.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And the prevailing explanation seems to be that he's funding Blue Origin with these sales.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The leading theory is that it is to fund Blue Origin, a space exploration company that Bezos founded in September 2000.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, his space company—he founded that back in 2000, didn't he?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, his space company-he founded that back in two thousand, didn't he?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The leading theory is that it is to fund Blue Origin, a space exploration company that Bezos founded in September 2000.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, October 2000. He's been pretty open about using his Amazon stock to bankroll it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, October two thousand. He's been pretty open about using his Amazon stock to bankroll it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The leading theory is that it is to fund Blue Origin, a space exploration company that Bezos founded in September 2000.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: I mean, at a space summit in 2017, he mentioned exactly that strategy. It's uh, kind of his thing now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I mean, at a space summit in twenty seventeen, he mentioned exactly that strategy. It's uh, kind of his thing now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Bezos told journalists at a space exploration conference in 2017 that he was funding Blue Origin by selling some of his Amazon shares.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And the shares he just sold were around 1,895 dollars each, but the price has dipped a bit since then.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the shares he just sold were around eighteen ninety five dollars each, but the price has dipped a bit since then.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: According to documents filed on Monday afternoon with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the worlds richest man sold over 530,000 shares of Amazon when the stock price was around $1,900 a share. On Monday, the stock closed at $1,765 a share.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, closed at 1,770 on Tuesday. Still, when you're worth over 110 billion, a dip like that is… manageable.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, closed at seventeen seventy on Tuesday. Still, when you're worth over one hundred ten billion, a dip like that is... manageable.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On Monday, the stock closed at $1,765 a share. As the richest man on earth, Bezos is now worth an estimated $110.1 billion, using Mondays closing share price for Amazon.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. And Amazon itself isn't commenting on the sales, which isn't surprising.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. And Amazon itself isn't commenting on the sales, which isn't surprising.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A spokesman for Amazon has not commented on the purpose for Bezos last stock sales.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: No, but it's pretty clear where the money's going. Blue Origin's gotta be expensive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, but it's pretty clear where the money's going. Blue Origin's gotta be expensive.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. Rockets don't come cheap, even for the richest person on the planet.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. Rockets don't come cheap, even for the richest person on the planet.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's wild to think he can just sell stock and fund a whole space company like that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's wild to think he can just sell stock and fund a whole space company like that.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but hey, if you've got it, why not shoot for the stars, literally?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but hey, if you've got it, why not shoot for the stars, literally?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: True! Though I'd probably just buy an island or something.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: True! Though I'd probably just buy an island or something.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right? Different priorities for different billionaires.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? Different priorities for different billionaires.

HostB: Yeah, and it's not the first time either—he sold a huge chunk back in July too, right? Like, 1.3 billion dollars after taxes.
HostA: Exactly. And the prevailing explanation seems to be that he's funding Blue Origin with these sales.
HostB: Oh, his space company—he founded that back in 2000, didn't he?
HostA: Yeah, October 2000. He’s been pretty open about using his Amazon stock to bankroll it.
HostB: I mean, at a space summit in 2017, he mentioned exactly that strategy. It’s uh, kind of his thing now.
HostA: And the shares he just sold were around 1,895 dollars each, but the price has dipped a bit since then.
HostB: Right, closed at 1,770 on Tuesday. Still, when you're worth over 110 billion, a dip like that is… manageable.
HostA: Absolutely. And Amazon itself isn't commenting on the sales, which isn't surprising.
HostB: No, but it’s pretty clear where the money's going. Blue Origin’s gotta be expensive.
HostA: For sure. Rockets don't come cheap, even for the richest person on the planet.
HostB: It’s wild to think he can just sell stock and fund a whole space company like that.
HostA: Yeah, but hey, if you've got it, why not shoot for the stars, literally?
